content.heading: Welcome
content.text:
This session explores events and systemic structures. 

Find a comfortable position and begin the exercise when you are ready.

content.heading: Reflection
content.text: You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own. 1 minute starting now.

content.heading: Reflection
content.text:
How was that experience for you?

How might analyzing events and behaviors in this way help us empathize with others?

How might it help us practice self-compassion towards ourselves?
How might analyzing events and behaviors in this way help us empathize with others? • How might it help us practice self-compassion towards ourselves?
content.heading: How can this help us empathize with others and ourselves?
How can the Iceberg help understand interdependence?

content.text:
Well done. Today, we’ve explored systems thinking by using the metaphor of an iceberg.

This can help us to more deeply understand an action or event by considering the many variables and factors that have led to it, including underlying systemic structures.
content.heading: Systems thinking
Systems thinking
content.text: Rather than placing all blame or praise on an individual, we can identify how internal and external structures, some of which are beyond an individual’s control, contribute to events. This understanding can deepen an appreciation of interdependence and common humanity.

If you’re up for it, you can continue with this mission.

Reflect on a situation where you had a difficult encounter with a thought or another person. How could using the model of iceberg help to encourage compassion for yourself and others in that thought or situation?
content.heading: Systems thinking

en.name: Iceberg

hostNotes.text: > Press play to start the exercise

en.description: We are going to explore a deeper way of looking at events, by analyzing how they rest upon systemic structures. Addressing these deeper systemic structures can help us to understand events and patterns of behavior better, and provide insights that help us to take more effective action in changing such patterns.

hostNotes.text:
Welcome. I am X and today we will work for around 30 minutes on xx

We’ll be doing xx ex. meditation followed by time for reflection and sharing with each other.

Let’s start with a mini check-in. How are you feeling right now? Please answer in two-three words. X, would you like to start?

> Let everyone in the session, including yourself, check in one by one.

Thank you all for checking in. Let’s get started.

Find a comfortable position. I will start the audio exercise and we'll meet back here afterwards. 

> Push play to start the audio exercise

Now we’ll take 1 minute to reflect on our own.

xxMain question

xxFurther explanations of main question if needed

You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own. 1 minute starting now.

> Press play to start the timer.

That’s 1 minute and it’s time to move on.

Now we are getting into the sharing part. We have three rules for sharing:

1. **What is said in here, stays in here.**
2. **All you need to do is listen.** There is no fixing, helping or advice-giving needed. We are just showing up and exploring what ourselves and others are going through.

3. **Everything on the inside is okay.** Anger, love, hatred, sadness. Whatever shows up. No wrongs, no rights. It is what it is.

There will be a timer set for 2 minutes as an indicator. If you don’t want to share you can always say ‘pass’.

Who would like to start?

> Let everyone (or as many as you got time for) share one by one. Press play to start the timer. Re-start for each new sharing.

Thank you so much everyone.

Well done. If you’re up for it, you can continue what we started here today with a mission to bring this into your everyday life.

xx mission description

Before we leave this space let’s do a mini check-out. 

How are you feeling right now? Has anything shifted? Please answer in two-three words.

Who would like to start?

> Let everyone in the session check out one by one.

Thank you all for checking out and for joining this session today.

> Finish session to send everyone off to the exit experience.

content.text:
Well done.

Summary.

If you’re up for it, you can continue with this mission.

mission description

hostNotes.text: > Start the session when you're ready to go

pt-BR.description: Vamos explorar uma forma mais profunda de olhar para os acontecimentos, analisando como eles se apoiam em estruturas sistêmicas. Abordar essas estruturas mais profundas pode nos ajudar a compreender melhor os eventos e padrões de comportamento, além de oferecer insights que ajudam a agir de maneira mais eficaz para mudar esses padrões.

hostNotes.text: >Pressione play para iniciar o exercício

pt-BR.name: Iceberg

content.heading: Bem-vindo(a)
content.text:
Esta sessão explora eventos e estruturas sistêmicas.

Encontre uma posição confortável e inicie o exercício quando estiver pronto.

content.heading: Reflexão
content.text: Você pode fazer anotações em um pedaço de papel ou apenas mentalmente. E não existe certo ou errado aqui, nossas respostas são pessoais. 1 minuto a partir de agora.

content.heading: Reflexão
content.text:
Como foi essa experiência para você?

De que forma analisar eventos e comportamentos dessa maneira pode nos ajudar a ter mais empatia pelos outros?

Como isso pode nos ajudar a praticar a autocompaixão?

content.heading: Como isso pode nos ajudar a ter empatia com os outros e conosco?
content.text:
De que forma analisar eventos e comportamentos dessa maneira pode nos ajudar a ter mais empatia pelos outros?  
Como isso pode nos ajudar a praticar a autocompaixão?

content.heading: Como o Iceberg pode ajudar a entender a interdependência?
Pensamento sistêmico
content.text:
Muito bem. Hoje exploramos o pensamento sistêmico usando a metáfora do iceberg.

Isso pode nos ajudar a compreender mais profundamente uma ação ou evento ao considerar as muitas variáveis e fatores que levaram a ele, incluindo estruturas sistêmicas subjacentes.

content.heading: Pensamento sistêmico
content.text: Em vez de atribuir toda a culpa ou mérito a um indivíduo, podemos identificar como estruturas internas e externas, algumas das quais estão além do controle da pessoa, contribuem para os acontecimentos. Esse entendimento pode aprofundar a apreciação da interdependência e da humanidade comum.

content.heading: Pensamento sistêmico
content.text:
Se quiser, você pode continuar com esta sugestão.

Reflita sobre uma situação em que você teve um encontro difícil com um pensamento ou com outra pessoa. Como o uso do modelo do iceberg poderia ajudar a incentivar a compaixão por si mesmo e pelos outros nesse pensamento ou situação?
